posts.name: evanperryg
posts.cooked:
1732 keeps a little “e-waste bin” for any dead electronics. Before it got hauled off the other day, I decided to pull out a dead Spark Max, mostly just to see what was inside. I’ll write about that eventually, but what I did find surprising was this particular Spark’s failure mode.

A Spark Max has two boards inside. One has all the high-current stuff, the other has the brains / CAN driver / etc. The two boards connect to each other with a pair of 10-pin headers.

When I tried to pry the power board out of the housing, one of the housings for those headers popped off. Okay, I’m a klutz, whatever. The more surprising thing is that it took 5 of the pins with it. See how those 5 pins are bent up?

2025-01-21-124709 1920×1080 142 KB

2025-01-21-124709 1920×1080 142 KB

2025-01-21-124709 1920×1080 142 KB

What’s interesting here is that those pins aren’t broken. They’re fully intact, but they aren’t attached to the pads beneath them. There’s no solder residue left behind on the pins. There’s solder on the pads, and it’s indented with the shape of the pins.

This appears to have happened to the other connector, too:

2025-01-21-131105 1920×1080 101 KB

2025-01-21-131105 1920×1080 101 KB

2025-01-21-131105 1920×1080 101 KB

I can’t prove that poor solder joints caused this Spark Max to fail, but there are no obvious signs of component failure elsewhere on the board.

Does anyone else have any dead Spark Maxes they’d be willing to take apart? Can you see if a similar thing going on?

By the way, the power board in my Spark Max shows the text “REV-11-2158 / REV. E3 BOT”

posts.name: Will Toth
posts.cooked: Curious if the device works again if you bend the pins back down and try to reconnect them?

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked: Those connectors would have the 6 gate drive signals on some of the pins. If some of the connections are open circuit, the controller chip might not have proper control over the output transistors. Since the gates of the MOSFETs are very high impedance it is possible for the uncontrolled MOSFETs to turn on at the wrong time and cause a shoot-through condition where the upper and lower devices in a half-bridge both are in the On-state, shorting the 12V supply. It is quite possible that some of the MOSFETs are already damaged.

posts.name: Will Toth
posts.cooked: In theory the DRV chip should prevent that case, even by default if the SPI comms are blocked due to pins missing.

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked: That’s interesting. All the microcontrollers tailored for motor control applications provide 6 PWM outputs directly instead of sending the gate signals via some sort of serial bus.

posts.name: Kevin Forbes
posts.cooked:
The motor driver (TI DRV8320S ) is on the power board.

I was curious and dug up an old failed board. Same lack of solder on top of those connectors pins. Board rev in silk is “E3 BOT” image 1719×1294 195 KB It’s likely a non-issue, if there’s a sufficient solder fillet on the sides of the pins and it takes substantial force to remove the connector.

image 1719×1294 195 KB

image 1719×1294 195 KB

posts.name: evanperryg
posts.cooked:
That’s the thing, I wouldn’t call anything I did while disassembling the Spark “substantial.” For the most part, you just pop the screws out and the whole thing falls apart. I poked the header again and two more pins fell off.

It doesn’t seem like a likely root cause, but it’s certainly weird.

posts.name: evanperryg
posts.cooked: I tried to get the controller board talking over SWD, and it’s so dead that my J-Link stops talking to the PC as soon as I connect it to the board. So, clearly something is very, VERY cooked, and the headers certainly have nothing to do with that. Not directly, at least.
